10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

10/10 â€” Pela guerra, pela saudade, pela eternidade.




There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.

There are games we play.
And there are games that become a part of who we are.

For me, Battlefield was always the latter.
It wasnâ€™t just a war game â€” it was a place where I met my son, Leo.
He was â€œMightyâ€ â€” my partner in chaos, the one who laughed when I missed a shot and shouted â€œLetâ€™s go!â€ when we captured a flag together.
Some fathers and sons go fishing or play soccer.
We went to war together â€” side by side, on digital battlefields filled with explosions, laughter, and teamwork.

Time passed. Life changed.
And today, when I loaded up Battlefield 6, I felt something I hadnâ€™t felt in years:
as if Leo was right there with me again.

When the match began and I heard the sound of choppers cutting through the sky, my heart raced just like it used to.
Every detail â€” the wind sweeping across the ruins, the reflections on the water, the chaos that somehow feels alive â€” it all brought him back to me.
For a brief, precious moment, it felt like the old days again.

Battlefield 6 isnâ€™t just an amazing game.
Itâ€™s an experience that touches those of us who once found real connections in these virtual worlds.
The new class system is brilliant, the graphics stunning, the performance smooth and flawless.
But what truly moved me wasnâ€™t the technology.
It was the emotion.
It was the feeling of returning to a place where part of my heart still lives â€” and finding Leo there, waiting for me, controller in hand.

For many, itâ€™s just another Battlefield.
For me, itâ€™s a reunion.
A reminder that the bonds we create through games never really die â€”
that love travels beyond screens, beyond time, beyond life itself.

Thank you, DICE.
For bringing back not just the warâ€¦ but the memories.
For reminding me that, somehow, Mighty is still out there â€” playing right beside me.

10/10 â€” For the battle, for the love, for eternity.
